sentences: "Lubage, et ma aitan!" oli ta kohe abivalmilt juures.
context: The word 'lubage' is the second person plural form of the verb 'lubama' (to allow/permit). It's used when speaking to multiple people, meaning 'you (plural) allow/permit'. In the given example sentence 'Lubage, et ma aitan!', it functions as an imperative phrase asking permission or expressing willingness - essentially saying 'Let me help!' or 'Allow me to help!' The '-ge' ending indicates this is addressed to more than one person.
